units.title: Organoid Derivation from Tissue
units.text: Patient resection material is cut into small pieces, washed thoroughly and digested with collagenase. After additional washing and filtration, the digested tissue is plated in basement membrane extract (BME) and supplemented with expansion medium (Fig. 2b,c).
units.rationale: This is a clear, actionable step in the protocol for initiating organoid culture from tissue samples.

units.title: BME Plating for 3D Culture
units.text: BME, a gel-like substance that polymerizes at temperatures above 10 °C, is used to mimic the extracellular matrix and provide support for 3D organoids (Fig. 2d,e).
units.rationale: Describes a critical procedural step for creating the 3D environment necessary for organoid growth.

units.title: Organoid Passaging via Fragments
units.text: We describe both single-cell organoid passaging by trypsinization (Step 43A; Fig. 2g) and passaging via organoid fragments by mechanical disruption, referred to as shearing (Step 43B; Fig. 2g).
units.rationale: Provides specific, actionable instructions for maintaining organoid cultures through passaging methods.

units.title: Optimizing Passaging Timing
units.text: The best moment to passage is just before organoids in the center of the BME drop start dying, characterized by shedding of debris or a darker appearance, or when organoids reach a diameter larger than 300 μm (further referred to as a 'confluent well').
units.rationale: Gives a clear, measurable criterion for when to perform a key procedural step in organoid maintenance.

units.title: Lipofectamine-Based Transfection
units.text: We discuss three different methods for genetically modifying breast organoids, including Lipofectamine 2000 for transient transfection with moderate-to-high efficiency (Step 65A), electroporation for transient transfection with high efficiency (Step 65B; used for Fig. S4 of ref. 7) or lentiviral transduction (Step 65C).
units.rationale: Outlines a specific, actionable genetic manipulation procedure with defined reagents and steps.

units.title: Electroporation for Genetic Manipulation
units.text: Electroporation for transient transfection with high efficiency (Step 65B; used for Fig. S4 of ref. 7)
units.rationale: Specifies a precise method and step number for genetic modification of organoids.

units.title: Lentiviral Transduction
units.rationale: Identifies a defined genetic manipulation protocol step with a specific method and reference.

units.title: Clonal Selection After Genetic Manipulation
units.text: Using single cells, as opposed to fragments, will increase the likelihood that the organoids growing out after selection (e.g., by puromycin) indeed originate from single cells and are, thus, clonal.
units.rationale: Describes a critical procedural decision for ensuring clonality after genetic modification.

units.title: Xenotransplantation via Orthotopic Injection
units.text: Finally, we introduce an optimized method for orthotopic organoid transplantation in mice, which includes injection of organoids and estrogen pellets without the need for surgery.
units.rationale: Details a key in vivo procedure with a specific, non-surgical method for tumor modeling.

units.title: Organoid Cryopreservation
units.text: We recommend cryopreserving at least six cryovials for each newly established organoid culture at an early passage (< passage 5).
units.rationale: Provides a clear, actionable guideline for long-term storage of organoid cultures.
